questions.answerA: Cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Cover your arms completely, but leave your legs exposed.
questions.answerC: Cover your legs completely, but leave your arms exposed.
questions.answerD: Be whatever makes you most comfortable, regardless of safety.
questions.explanation: To be adequately protected while riding, you should wear a jacket and pants that completely cover your arms and legs.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerA: Eye contact
questions.answerB: Using a turn signal
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerB: Tailgate other drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Are unimportant.
questions.answerB: Should only be done on long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerD: Are not helpful since you can’t do anything about what is behind you.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal searching routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: Which types of brakes do most motorcycles have?
questions.answerA: Front and emergency
questions.answerB: Rear and emergency
questions.answerC: Front and rear
questions.answerD: Only a front brake
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have one brake for each wheel. The front brake carries more braking power than the rear brake.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator:
questions.answerA: Plans to turn left.
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: A linked braking system:
questions.answerA: Connects the front and rear brakes, applying both brakes when either brake lever is applied.
questions.answerB: Connects the front brake to the gear shifter, applying the brake when the rider downshifts.
questions.answerC: Connects the rear brake to a foot control.
questions.answerD: Connects the rear brake to a switch on the handlebar.
questions.explanation: A linked braking system connects the front and rear brakes on a motorcycle. This system applies braking pressure to both brakes when either the front or rear lever is used. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerA: Downshifting.
questions.answerB: Upshfting.
questions.answerC: Cross-shifting.
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: When a group of riders is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should:
questions.answerA: Pass in pairs.
questions.answerB: Pass in a staggered formation with several riders passing at the same time.
questions.answerC: Pass one at a time.
questions.answerD: Avoid passing.
questions.explanation: When a group of motorcyclists is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should pass the vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete their pass before the next rider's pass begins.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure
questions.answerB: General wear
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: Gloves can:
questions.answerA: Make it difficult to control a motorcycle and should be avoided.
questions.answerB: Help other drivers identify you.
questions.answerC: Provide an improved grip on the handlebars.
questions.answerD: Offer no protection.
questions.explanation: Gloves can provide you with an improved grip on your motorcycle's handlebars. They can also protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You must complete the pass without exceeding the speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone if the pass was started before the no passing zone began.
questions.answerC: You may exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerD: You should pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerA: The steering will feel heavy.
questions.answerB: The steering will feel loose.
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerA: They make you drowsy.
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: How can you increase your ability to be seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Make sure you always ride using your headlight.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to vehicles in front of you.
questions.explanation: To maximize your ability to be seen at an intersection, ride with your headlight on and select a lane position that provides oncoming traffic with the best view of your motorcycle. Maintain a space cushion that allows you enough space to take evasive action if a hazard arises. You should never assume that making eye contact with a driver will be enough to make them consciously register your presence.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: As the motorcycle’s weight moves forward while braking, you:
questions.answerA: Can apply the front brake harder.
questions.answerB: Should lessen the amount of pressure on the front brake.
questions.answerC: Can apply the rear brake harder.
questions.answerD: Lose traction.
questions.explanation: As your weight shifts forward while you are braking, the amount of traction available to the front wheel increases. This means that you can begin to apply the front brake harder.

questions.question: Motorcycles are allowed to travel in High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes:
questions.answerA: Only if it is raining.
questions.answerB: Only on weekends.
questions.answerC: Only when transporting a passenger.
questions.answerD: At any time.
questions.explanation: In Washington State, unless otherwise posted, motorcyclists are allowed to use High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes at any time. HOV lanes are identifiable by diamond marking on the pavement and signs.

questions.question: If you are using an unfamiliar motorcycle, what should you do before riding?
questions.answerA: Ride like you would on your bike, since all bikes are about the same.
questions.answerB: Check the controls and shift pattern.
questions.answerC: Take the owner’s word that everything is in working order.
questions.answerD: Assume you know where all the controls are located.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are slightly different, so you should check the controls and make sure you know the gear pattern before riding an unfamiliar motorcycle. Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times prior to riding.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat and you must brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake of the tire that is not flat.
questions.answerB: Apply the brake of the tire that is flat.
questions.answerC: Apply both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use either brake.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat and you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat (if you are certain of which tire that is).

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerA: Made of leather.
questions.answerB: Made of wool.
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: At high speeds.
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerA: Seen by other motorists.
questions.answerB: Faster than other vehicles.
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: When riding in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlight.
questions.answerB: Use your low beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Use no lights.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the low and high beams.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in foggy conditions. Do not use your high beams when riding near other vehicles.

questions.question: Which portion of the lane should be avoided?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: No portion of the lane should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for riding conditions.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerA: It affects how you steer.
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
questions.answerD: You won’t be able to use the brake.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it affects your ability to steer. If your front tire goes flat while you are riding, safely exit the road as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerB: So you can tailgate.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain your usual space cushion.
questions.answerB: Brake later than usual.
questions.answerC: Ride a little more slowly than usual.
questions.answerD: Ride a little faster than usual.
questions.explanation: Your motorcycle will sit lower than normal under the additional weight of a passenger. To accommodate, you should ride a bit more slowly than usual, particularly when riding through curves, through corners, or over bumps. The extra weight also means that your motorcycle will take longer than usual to speed up, slow down, or stop, so you should maintain a larger space cushion when carrying a passenger.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Is less effective than goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face if you are involved in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for googles or a face shield.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Twice a month.
questions.explanation: Perform an inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This takes only a few minutes and helps prevent dangerous situations before entering traffic.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerB: Looks good.
questions.answerC: Does not have a chin strap.
questions.answerD: Protects the wearer's hearing.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerA: Shoes with long heels.
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Which of the following provides the best protection?
questions.answerA: Sunglasses
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: Face shield
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for the wearer's entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles may protect someone's eyes, but not the rest of their face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerA: Dry pavement
questions.answerB: Gravel
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: If you find your motorcycle being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Ride alongside the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Ride while using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking alcohol and wants to drive, which of the following should you not do?
questions.answerA: Encourage friends to talk them out of driving.
questions.answerB: Arrange for other transportation.
questions.answerC: Tell them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerD: Slow their pace of drinking.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from driving while under the influence of alcohol. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow their pace of drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerB: When stopped at an intersection
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: In any crash, you have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Wear an approved helmet.
questions.answerB: Wear face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Have a windshield.
questions.explanation: You can reduce your risk of injury when riding a motorcycle by wearing an approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerB: Keep the motorcycle from leaning.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothing.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Switching into a neutral gear.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: If a tailgater is following you too closely, it is advisable to flash your brake light before you begin to decelerate. The tailgater may be concentrating on you and may not be aware of hazards farther down the road that you are slowing to avoid.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen during daylight hours, you should:
questions.answerA: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothing all the time.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder and stay out of traffic.
questions.answerD: Wear dark clothing all the time.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding to maximize your chances of being seen, even during the day.

questions.question: Braking in a turn is:
questions.answerA: Easier than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: More difficult than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Done safely by using the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Done safely by using the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Braking in a turn is not as easy as braking on a straightaway. It is possible to use both brakes to brake in a turn, but the operator must know the proper technique and exercise great care.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: A way to lower the risk of being involved in a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.answerB: Not look ahead while riding.
questions.answerC: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerD: Ride in the parts of a lane that make it difficult to be seen.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: When checking tire pressure:
questions.answerA: Eyeballing the tire is a good method.
questions.answerB: Use a tire gauge.
questions.answerC: It is best to squeeze the tire.
questions.answerD: Compare the height of the tire to another tire.
questions.explanation: You should use a tire gauge to check the tire pressure before every ride. An under-inflated tire may still look okay, so a visual check is not enough.

questions.question: You should do all of the following to lesson your chances of being in a crash, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible by wearing proper clothing and using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions by using your turn signals and brake light.
questions.answerC: Search for hazards in your path.
questions.answerD: Hope the other drivers see you.
questions.explanation: To minimize your risk of a crash, ensure that you are visible to other drivers, communicating your intentions to other drivers, and maintaining a cushion of space around you. You should search for, identify, and separate hazards. Be prepared to react to anything that happens.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerA: Far from home.
questions.answerB: On short trips.
questions.answerC: On long rides.
questions.answerD: Several hours into the ride.
questions.explanation: Most crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When roads are slippery.
questions.answerB: When it is sunny outside.
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: A helmet will not provide the best possible protection:
questions.answerA: If it is certified by the DOT.
questions.answerB: If it fits snugly.
questions.answerC: If it is free of defects.
questions.answerD: If it has cracks.
questions.explanation: A helmet should meet U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards and fit snugly all the way around to provide maximum protection. It should be free of defects such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: The center portion of a traffic lane is where:
questions.answerA: Debris and oil drippings from cars often collect.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle riders should always travel for safety.
questions.answerC: Most accidents happen.
questions.answerD: Drivers are least likely to see a motorcyclist.
questions.explanation: The centermost portion of a lane is where debris and oil drippings from cars often collect. Other hazards, such as utility hole covers, can also be found in the centermost portion of the lane.

questions.question: When turning left, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the right handgrip.
questions.answerB: Press the left handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press both handgrips at the same time.
questions.answerD: Not press either handgrip.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle must lean to make a turn. To make it lean in the appropriate direction, press the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: To best control a motorcycle, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Sit with their arms fully extended.
questions.answerB: Use their arms to hold their body up.
questions.answerC: Keep their knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so that you can use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerA: Engine braking.
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have operated the involved motorcycle for less than six months.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders with less than six months of experience on the motorcycle being used.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Squeeze the front brake and press the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Grab at the front brake and squeeze the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Jam on the front brake and grab at the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Press down on the front brake and jam on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: To brake, squeeze the front brake lever and press down on the rear brake pedal. Always use both brakes when slowing or stopping.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, it is important to ride on the left side of your lane because:
questions.answerA: The right side could be slippery.
questions.answerB: It will give you the best chance of spotting hazards in the next lane.
questions.answerC: People don’t usually expect to be passed on their left.
questions.answerD: It will place you in the rearview mirror of the car in front of you.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will increase your line of sight and make your more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerB: Wool
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: As an operator, you should prepare a passenger to ride by instructing them to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as possible.
questions.answerC: Maintain a large space between themselves and you.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler and chains.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerA: One second
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.
